Problem:
Examine the behavior of a linear integral transformation defined by \\(I[f](t) = \\int_0^t e^{-sA} f(s) ds\\) where A is a constant matrix and f is a vector-valued function. We assess the effect of a function perturbation on the transformed system where \\(f(s)\\) is replaced by \\(g(s) = e^{Bs} f(s)\\), with B being another constant matrix.

If the function \\(g(s) = e^{Bs} f(s)\\) replaces \\(f(s)\\) in the integral transformation without further interventions, does \\(I[g](t)\\) at time T differ from \\(I[f](t)\\) computed directly using the original \\(f(s)\\)?
Explanation: The perturbation of the input function to \\(g(s)\\), induced by \\(e^{Bs}\\), modifies the integral formula. Since the transformation by B affects the integrand by a multiplicative factor which depends on s, the output of the integral transformation \\(I[g](t)\\) will generally differ from \\(I[f](t)\\) due to the interaction between B and A within the integral expression.
